snippet: Voting turnout a week after the 2012 storm did not suffer as much as some had feared, but the makeshift adjustments exposed shortcomings that experts and officials say require attention.
abstract: Officials say they are responding to lessons learned during 2012 presidential election, when one week after Hurricane Sandy they were forced to scramble to relocate polling places and devise ways for displaced residents to vote; New York Sen Charles E Schumer plans to introduce legislation to require states to develop disaster contingency plans for elections for federal offices.
lead_paragraph: Voting turnout a week after the 2012 storm did not suffer as much as some had feared, but the makeshift adjustments exposed shortcomings that experts and officials say require attention.

headline.main: Using Hurricane Sandy as a Lesson for Future Elections
